did.abstract: Professor of English at University of Michigan. Correspondence, diaries, and topical files relating to his interest in English grammar and usage, his evaluation of various dictionaries, his interest in Polish-American relations, and the controversy surrounding Henshaw Ward's denial of Peary's discovery of the North Pole.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Carlton F. Wells (donor no. 2708) and came to the library in multiple accessions.

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Carlton F. Wells papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Carlton Frank Wells was born April 30, 1898 in Vicksburg, MI, the son of Frank W. and Anna H. Wells. After graduation from Western State Normal High School in Kalamazoo, he entered the University of Michigan from which he received his bachelor's degree in 1920 and his master's degree in 1922. Wells joined the faculty at the University of Michigan in 1921 as an instructor in English. He would teach in the English Department until his retirement in 1968. During his career, Wells served as chairman of Freshman English in the Literary College from 1935 to 1949. He was also faculty advisor to foreign students from 1922 to 1929. Toward the close of World War II and immediately thereafter, he served as chairman of the Michigan Committee of Americans for Poland.

Professor Wells was a member of Phi Beta Kappa, the National Council of Teachers of English and the Michigan Council of Teachers of English. He was co-editor of several texts for freshman English and in 1962, he published, with a colleague The Recognition of Emily Dickinson. For 10 years following his retirement, he served as secretary-treasurer of the U of M Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa. Wells died December 4, 1994.

scopecontent.p: The Wells collection is comprised of the following series: Subject file; Personal diaries; Robert E. Peary; and Other papers.

scopecontent.p: The Subject file, arranged alphabetically, includes correspondence with Wells' many friends and colleagues as well as other files detailing his scholarly interests and organizational activities. There are, for instance, extensive files relating to his analysis of new editions of dictionaries, particularly Webster's New World Dictionary 1953 edition, to his participation with the Michigan Committee of Americans for Poland, and to his interest the usage of the English language.

did.unittitle: American College Dictionary (1947) vs. Webster's New World Dictionary (1953)
Ellis, William, re. publication of his manuscript Pick-Up 1937-1938
Committee reports and compiled biographical material
Michigan Committee of Americans for Poland 1943-1960
Osborn, Chase, re. his book about Henry Schoolcraft and Hiawatha legend 1958
Trip to Turkey by Helen Wells 1927-1928
Correspondence with and about Gerald L.K.-Smith and Father Charles Coughlin

scopecontent.p: The Personal diaries series begins in 1911 and runs almost continuously until his death in 1994. There are but a few early gaps in coverage, 1912 to 1917. Beyond that, the scores of volumes show Wells to be a conscientious observer of current and local events. This series also includes a few volumes of his wife, Cecilia D. Wells' diaries.

The Robert E. Peary series which came to the library subsequent to the Subject file series concerns the controversy surrounding Henshaw Ward's denial that Peary was the discoverer of the North Pole. The topic was one that intrigued Wells over many years but especially in his retirement. Included is both collected materials and correspondence with individuals knowledgeable about the topic.

did.unittitle: Manuscript copy of "The Peary Myth: A Study in American Glory"
Master Contents list of Peary Series

scopecontent.p: The Other papers series includes correspondence from Wells' later career and retirement. There are also photographs and a scrapbook of trips taken by the University of Michigan's Cosmopolitan Club, 1922-1928.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook re trips taken by U-M's Cosmopolitan Club, 1922-1928
